sub_topic: Jacobians of algebraic curves and their properties
message_1: Consider the algebraic curve defined by the equation $y^2=x^3+7x+1$. Find the Jacobian of this curve at the point $(1, \sqrt{9})$.
message_2:
To find the Jacobian of the curve defined by the equation $y^2 = x^3 + 7x + 1$, we first need to find the partial derivatives of the equation with respect to x and y. Let $F(x, y) = y^2 - x^3 - 7x - 1$. Then, we have:

$\frac{\partial F}{\partial x} = -3x^2 - 7$

$\frac{\partial F}{\partial y} = 2y$

Now, we can find the Jacobian matrix at the point $(1, \sqrt{9}) = (1, 3)$:

$J_F(1, 3) = \begin{bmatrix} \frac{\partial F}{\partial x}(1, 3) & \frac{\partial F}{\partial y}(1, 3) \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} -3(1)^2 - 7 & 2(3) \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} -10 & 6 \end{bmatrix}$

So, the Jacobian of the curve at the point $(1, \sqrt{9})$ is $\begin{bmatrix} -10 & 6 \end{bmatrix}$.
